questions.question:
Question 1: A male infant born at 34 weeks of gestation by emergency LSCS was found to have the 
following finding on histopathological examination of his umbilical cord. Anomalies of which 
of the following systems are most likely to be found in this infant?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the presence of a single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased 
risk for an occult renal anomaly. The histopathological image of the cross-section of the umbilical cord shows 2 vessels as marked, 
a thin-walled umbilical vein and a thicker-walled umbilical artery. 26 
Sold by @itachibot The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most 
common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The 
incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Trisomy 18 is a common association.

questions.question:
Question 2: On a particularly busy day in the labor room, you are requested by the PG to take 
anthropometric measurements and calculate the ponderal index of a baby while she attends 
to another baby. You find the ponderal index to be 1.45. Which of the following organs is 
unlikely to be affected in this neonate?
questions.explanation:
A ponderal index of <2 suggests asymmetric intrauterine growth 
restriction. Asymmetric IUGR is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, 
where there is no sparing of head growth. Ponderal index = Birth weight (gm)/Length (cm)3 x 100. It is a weight-height-related parameter used as an indicator of fetal growth status. SymmetricIUGR 
Asymmetric IUGR Insult occurs inlate gestation Insult on fetal growth occurs

and weight areequallyaffecte

or equal to2 A ponderal indexless than 2 Caused by placental insufficie 
ncy, pregnancy-induced hype

mal disorders, or TORCH inf 
ections 27 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: The ponderal index of a term baby delivered by elective cesarean section is 1.75. Which of the 
following is unlikely to be associated?
questions.explanation:
A ponderal index of 1.75 suggests intrauterine growth restriction. Gestational diabetes usually 
presents with fetal macrosomia. Maternal factors associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR): • Hypertension/renal disease • Diabetes with placental vasculopathy • Hypoxemia • Malnutrition • Chronic illness • Sickle cell anemia • Drugs (narcotics, alcohol, cigarettes, cocaine) • Maternal infection and parasite infestations

questions.question:
Question 4: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5kg male baby by normal 
delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against 
a diagnosis of prematurity?
questions.explanation:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity). No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of 
prematurity in a newborn. Note: Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of 
diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the 
pinna and upper back. Ear Scor 
e 0 
Pinna flat and stays folded; n 
o recoil 1 
Slightly curved pinna; soft; sl 
ow recoil 2 
Well-curved pinna; soft but r 
eady recoil 3 
Formed & firm, instant recoil 4 
Thick cartilage, ear stiff 28 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A lady with wrong dates and a corrected gestational age of 43 weeks presents with labor 
pains. The CTG suggests placental insufficiency, and she is taken up for emergency LSCS. 
Which of the following physical signs is unlikely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.explanation:
The physical sign of an infant born post-term (43 weeks) in association with presumed placental 
insufficiency is abundant hair (not scanty hair). Infants born post-term in association with presumed placental insufficiency may have various 
physical signs, together termed as postmaturity syndrome (or dysmaturity syndrome). These include: • Desquamation, pale skin, and long nails. • Loose skin around the thighs and buttocks. • Meconium-stained nails, skin, vernix, and umbilical cord. • Presence of placental membranes.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 34-year-old lady with an obstetric score of G3P2L2 delivers a baby boy at 43 weeks + 2 days 
period of gestation. Which of the following are unlikely to be associated in the given scenario? 21 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Anemia is not a complication of post-maturity. Polycythemia may be seen in neonates born after 
42 weeks of gestation. Complications of post-maturity include: • Perinatal depression • Meconium aspiration • Persistent pulmonary hypertension • Hypoglycemia • Hypocalcemia 29 
Sold by @itachibot • Polycythemia

questions.question:
Question 7: Immediately following vaginal delivery, a baby is noted to have a diffuse ecchymotic swelling 
on the scalp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is caput succedaneum. Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous 
fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It 
may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines. Option A: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 
1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after 
birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp. Option C: Subgaleal hemorrhages occur with the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the 
dural sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. Blood accumulates between the epicranial 
aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum and resolves over 2-3 weeks. Often associated with 
vacuum-assisted delivery. Option D: Epidural hemorrhages, usually traumatic in origin, are associated with cephalo-pelvic 
disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or occur as a result of mechanical 
assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not a feature of marking B?

options.a: Swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp
options.d: Appears only several hours after birth

questions.explanation:
The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the 
scalp. Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial 
bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is 
no discoloration of the overlying scalp. 30 
Sold by @itachibot Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. 
Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the 
associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs). Other markings- A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the 
scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first 
week of life. C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a 
large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries 
due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in 
hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures. D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic 
disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance 
in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

questions.question:
Question 9: A baby in the postnatal ward is noted to have paralysis of the left hand along with ipsilateral 
ptosis and miosis. What is the most likely cause?

options.d: Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome

questions.explanation:
Left-hand paralysis with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis in a newborn suggests a diagnosis of 
Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome. There is an injury to the 7th-8th cervical nerves and the 1st thoracic nerve. This produces 
a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist 
and fingers (C8) are mainly affected, and the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow 
flexed. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and 
miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1 thoracic root are also injured. Option A: Erb–Duchenne paralysis affects the 5th and 6th cervical nerves. There is loss of 
abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. Moro's reflex is absent on the 
affected side. 31 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Phrenic nerve palsy (3, 4, and 5 cervical nerves) results in diaphragmatic paralysis. It is 
characterized by cyanosis and irregular and labored breathing. Option C: Horner's syndrome is characterized by miosis, ptosis, enophthalmos, anhydrosis, and 
loss of ciliospinal reflex.

questions.question:
Question 10: Following a delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia, the baby is noted to have a deformity 
in the right upper limb. On inspection, the orthopedics JR notes an adducted, internally 
rotated arm and a pronated forearm. Which nerve roots are affected here?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Erb–Duchenne paralysis. The injury is limited to 
the 5th and 6th cervical nerve roots. The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation 
of the forearm. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. There is an asymmetric Moro's Reflex 32 
Sold by @itachibot Note: In shoulder dystocia, the most common nerve injury is to the C5-6 nerve root. The most common 
bone to fracture is the clavicle.

questions.question:
Question 11: A term infant develops jaundice at day 2 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed 
to the trunk by day 4. It completely disappeared by day 7 following phototherapy. Which of 
the following statements is false regarding the cause of this pattern of jaundice?

options.a: Due to a rise in unconjugated bilirubin
options.b: Due to limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver
options.c: Due to Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells
options.d: Due to increased breakdown of fetal red blood cells

questions.explanation:
The above pattern of jaundice is suggestive of physiological jaundice/icterus neonatorum. It is due 
to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with 
transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks on the 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases 
to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth. Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells leads to pathological jaundice. 33 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Depth of jaundice (degree of yellowness) should be carefully noted (light staining as lemon-yellow; 
deep staining as orange-yellow), as it is an important indicator of the level of jaundice. Earlier, the 
involvement of soles and palms indicated severe jaundice but deep yellow staining (even in 
absence of yellow soles or palms) may be associated with severe jaundice.

questions.question:
Question 12: A male infant with a birth weight of 3.2 Kg is admitted to the phototherapy unit with a total 
bilirubin of 11mg/dl at 36 hours of life. Which of the following statements does not describe 
pathological jaundice?

options.a: Jaundice appears within first 24 hours after birth
options.b: Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks
options.c: Jaundice associated with rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dl/24 hour
options.d: Jaundice seen in the mid-abdomen and soles

questions.explanation:
Jaundice associated with a rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dL/24 hours suggests 
physiological jaundice. Features suggestive of pathological jaundice: • Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth • Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant • Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level • Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in 
the mid-abdominal region ( 15 mg/dL) and soles ( 20 mg/dL) • Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy • Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving 
phototherapy

questions.question:
Question 13: The peripheral smear of a newborn baby girl sent on day 2 of life shows mild hemolysis. What 
is the most common cause of this finding in a newborn?
questions.explanation:
ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease of newborns and affects the 
firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical. This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh 
incompatibility does. It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of different blood 
type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross 
the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs. Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunization (natural 
antibodies), they are usually IgM, which do not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A 
antigen may be present, and these do cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic 
disease in the first-born infant (A-O is more common than B-O).

questions.question:
Question 14: A 3.3 Kg term neonate is admitted on day 3 of life with yellowish discoloration of the skin and 
is going to undergo phototherapy. What is the most effective wavelength of light used for 
treatment?
questions.explanation:
The most effective range of wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect 
hyperbilirubinemia is 460–490 nm (blue-green light). 34 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of 
light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms: • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by 
forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated 
state. • Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an 
unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation. • Photo-oxidation: minor method

questions.question:
Question 15: A mother noticed yellowish discoloration of her term newborn within the first 6 hours of life. 
On examination, jaundice extended up to the lower abdomen and thighs. Which of the 
following drugs can be administered along with phototherapy?
questions.explanation:
Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical 
therapy for pathological jaundice in neonates. It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme 
oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent 
phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is 
receiving phototherapy. Tolazoline is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that produces systemic and pulmonary 
vasodilatation, which is used to correct pulmonary artery vasospasm when it causes severe 
right-left shunting soon after birth. Tromethamine is an organic buffer used in the management of metabolic acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 16: 24 
Sold by @itachibot While on rounds in the postnatal ward, the senior PG shows you a baby with dark, 
grayish-brown skin discoloration. It is a term, AGA baby on day 7 of life. She tells you that it 
is a case of bronze baby syndrome. This syndrome is caused by:
questions.explanation:
The bronze baby syndrome is a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration in infants undergoing 
phototherapy; it mainly occurs in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia as an adverse effect of 35 
Sold by @itachibot phototherapy. Despite the bronze baby syndrome, phototherapy can continue if needed. Other complications of Phototherapy: • Loose stools • Erythematous macular rash • The purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia • Overheating • Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea) • Hypothermia from exposure Gray baby syndrome is an adverse effect of chloramphenicol. Redman syndrome is an adverse effect of vancomycin.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 3.2 Kg term neonate born to a primigravida with gestational diabetes presented to the OPD 
with complaints of lethargy, hypotonia, and difficulty in feeding. Periodic monitoring of blood 
glucose is being done. What blood glucose levels indicate a need for the treatment of neonatal 
hypoglycemia?
questions.explanation:
The cut-off for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia to start IV glucose is a blood glucose level 
of <40 mg/dL. Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when the blood glucose is <45 mg/dL. Clinically in 
neonates, hypoglycemia can be asymptomatic or symptomatic. The neonate presents with 
tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, tachypnea, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, 
difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia, and rarely cardiac arrest. Management in symptomatic neonates: • Blood glucose <40mg/dL: IV glucose infusion • Blood glucose <25mg/dL: Bolus IV dextrose 1-2 mL/kg followed by infusion at the rate of 
5-8mL/kg/min. Management in asymptomatic neonates: • Breastfeeding within 30 minutes • Start IV glucose therapy if blood glucose <35 mg/dL • Recheck blood glucose before the next feeding • Continue skin-to-skin care • Evaluation for other underlying illnesses The desired target glucose value is >50mg/dL and blood glucose should be rechecked until 
three normal values.

questions.question:
Question 18: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 
mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do?
questions.explanation:
36 
Sold by @itachibot In an infant of a diabetic mother with normal blood glucose levels, the next investigation to 
consider is serum calcium due to the high risk of developing hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia in these 
infants is attributed to the delayed response of the parathyroid hormone system. Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium concentration of less than 8 mg/dL for a term 
baby (ionized calcium below 4mg/dL) and less than 7 mg/dL for a preterm baby. Asymptomatic 
neonates can be managed conservatively with early nutrition. Symptomatic neonates should 
receive iv or oral calcium replacement. Maternal hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperglycemia, and the fetal pancreatic response leads to 
fetal hyperinsulinemia, which causes neonatal hypoglycemia. Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as 
blood glucose <40 mg/dL (plasma glucose <45 mg/dL). The infant tends to be jittery, 
tremulous, hyperexcitable, hypotonic, lethargic, and poor sucking during the 1st three days after 
birth. These symptoms can also be related to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia which occur in 
the 1st 24 to 72 hours of life. Respiratory distress syndrome, macrosomia, hyperbilirubinemia, polycythemia, renal vein 
thrombosis, visceromegaly, heart failure, and persistent pulmonary hypertension are other 
features seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Congenital anomalies are seen in infants of mothers with pregestational diabetes. Neural tube 
defects (Encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels (TGA), 
ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis 
and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. Caudal regression syndrome is rare, but a specific anomaly seen in infants of diabetic mothers. 
Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following 
problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady?
questions.explanation:
Infants born to diabetic mothers may present with macrosomia (large for gestational age), 
hypocalcemia, and/ or neural tube defects. Other common features include: • Hypoglycemia • Respiratory distress syndrome • Cardiomegaly • Heart failure • Lumbosacral agenesis • Cardiac malformations • Ventricular or atrial septal defect • Transposition of the great vessels (most specific) • Truncus arteriosus • Double-outlet right ventricle • Tricuspid atresia 37 
Sold by @itachibot • Coarctation of the aorta Additional anomalies include neural tube defects, hydronephrosis, renal agenesis and dysplasia, 
duodenal or anorectal atresia, situs inversus, double ureter, and holoprosencephaly. 38 
Sold by @itachibot Diseases in Neonates requiring Special Care
